author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “Sometimes even to live is an act of courage.”

author: Seneca
message: “True happiness is to enjoy the present, without anxious dependence upon the future, not to amuse ourselves with either hopes or fears but to rest satisfied with what we have, which is sufficient, for he that is so wants nothing. The greatest blessings of mankind are within us and within our reach. A wise man is content with his lot, whatever it may be, without wishing for what he has not.”

author: Seneca
message: “Luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity.”

author: Seneca,
message: “All cruelty springs from weakness.”

author: Seneca's Morals: Of a Happy Life, Benefits, Anger and Clemency
message: “Religion is regarded by the common people as true, by the wise as false, and by rulers as useful.”

author: Seneca
message: “Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “Non est ad astra mollis e terris via" - "There is no easy way from the earth to the stars”

author: Seneca
message: “As is a tale, so is life: not how long it is, but how good it is, is what matters.”

author: Seneca
message: “Hang on to your youthful enthusiasms -- you’ll be able to use them better when you’re older.”

author: Seneca
message: “We suffer more often in imagination than in reality”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “You act like mortals in all that you fear, and like immortals in all that you desire”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca,
message: “The time will come when diligent research over long periods will bring to light things which now lie hidden. A single lifetime, even though entirely devoted to the sky, would not be enough for the investigation of so vast a subject... And so this knowledge will be unfolded only through long successive ages. There will come a time when our descendants will be amazed that we did not know things that are so plain to them... Many discoveries are reserved for ages still to come, when memory of us will have been effaced.”

author: On the Shortness of Life
message: “It is the power of the mind to be unconquerable.”

author: Seneca,
message: “If a man knows not to which port he sails, no wind is favorable.”

author: Natural Questions
message: “It is not that we have so little time but that we lose so much. ... The life we receive is not short but we make it so; we are not ill provided but use what we have wastefully.”

author: Seneca,
message: “It is not the man who has too little, but the man who craves more, that is poor. ”

author: The Stoic Philosophy of Seneca: Essays and Letters
message: “Begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life.”

author: Seneca the Younger
message: “What need is there to weep over parts of life? The whole of it calls for tears.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca,
message: “He who is brave is free”

author: On the Shortness of Life
message: “No man was ever wise by chance”

author: Seneca
message: “They lose the day in expectation of the night, and the night in fear of the dawn.”

author: Seneca
message: “Associate with people who are likely to improve you.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “I shall never be ashamed of citing a bad author if the line is good.”

author: Seneca
message: “If you really want to escape the things that harass you, what you’re needing is not to be in a different place but to be a different person.”

author: Seneca
message: “He suffers more than necessary, who suffers before it is necessary.”

author: Seneca,
message: “Only time can heal what reason cannot.”

author: On the Shortness of Life
message: “Until we have begun to go without them, we fail to realize how unnecessary many things are. We've been using them not because we needed them but because we had them.”

author: Seneca
message: “Most powerful is he who has himself in his own power.”

message: “Timendi causa est nescire -

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca,
message: “Life is like a play: it's not the length, but the excellence of the acting that matters.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca,
message: “For what prevents us from saying that the happy life is to have a mind that is free, lofty, fearless and steadfast - a mind that is placed beyond the reach of fear, beyond the reach of desire, that counts virtue the only good, baseness the only evil, and all else but a worthless mass of things, which come and go without increasing or diminishing the highest good, and neither subtract any part from the happy life nor add any part to it?

author: The Stoic Philosophy of Seneca: Essays and Letters
message: “Wealth is the slave of a wise man. The master of a fool ”

author: Seneca,
message: “Enjoy present pleasures in such a way as not to injure future ones.”

author: Moral Essays: Volume I De Providentia. De Constantia. De Ira. De Clementia
message: “Putting things off is the biggest waste of life: it snatches away each day as it comes, and denies us the present by promising the future. The greatest obstacle to living is expectancy, which hangs upon tomorrow, and loses today. You are arranging what lies in Fortune's control, and abandoning what lies in yours. What are you looking at? To what goal are you straining? The whole future lies in uncertainty: live immediately.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca,
message: “The sun also shines on the wicked.”

author: Letters from a Stoic
message: “As long as you live, keep learning how to live.”

author: Seneca
message: “A sword never kills anybody; it is a tool in the killer's hand.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “Leisure without books is death, and burial of a man alive.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “If you live in harmony with nature you will never be poor; if you live according what others think, you will never be rich.”

author: Seneca
message: “Fate leads the willing and drags along the reluctant.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “Every new beginning comes from some other beginning's end.”

author: Seneca,
message: “A gift consists not in what is done or given, but in the intention of the giver or doer.”

author: Letters from a Stoic
message: “We learn not in the school, but in life.”

author: Seneca
message: “People are frugal in guarding their personal property; but as soon as it comes to squandering time they are most wasteful of the one thing in which it is right to be stingy.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “Often a very old man has no other proof of his long life than his age.”

author: Seneca,
message: “Anger, if not restrained, is frequently more hurtful to us than the injury that provokes it.”

message: “We should every night call ourselves to an account;

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “Life is long, if you know how to use it.”

author: Seneca,
message: “errare humanum est, sed perseverare diabolicum: 'to err is human, but to persist (in the mistake) is diabolical.”

author: On the Shortness of Life
message: “We are more often frightened than hurt; and we suffer more from imagination than from reality”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca,
message: “Nothing is more honorable than a grateful heart.”

author: On the Shortness of Life
message: “There is no genius without a touch of madness.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “It does not matter how many books you have, but how good the books are which you have.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “To wish to be well is a part of becoming well.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca,
message: “I am not born for one corner; the whole world is my native land.”

author: On the Shortness of Life
message: “If anyone says that the best life of all is to sail the sea, and then adds that I must not sail upon a sea where shipwrecks are a common occurrence and there are often sudden storms that sweep the helmsman in an adverse direction, I conclude that this man, although he lauds navigation, really forbids me to launch my ship.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “While we wait for life, life passes”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “He who spares the wicked injures the good.”

author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca
message: “It is a rough road that leads to the heights of greatness.”

author: Seneca
message: “He who has injured thee was either stronger or weaker than thee. If weaker, spare him; if stronger, spare thyself.”
